docs.text:
BLAZE

A LIDAR mapping tool for processing point cloud data

Blaze is a LIDAR mapping tool designed for processing, analyzing, and visualizing point cloud data from LAS/LAZ files. Built with modern C++20, Blaze provides both command-line (blaze-cli) and graphical interfaces (Blaze and Blaze3D).

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Fast Processing: Optimized C++20 backend with OpenMP support.
  • Multiple Interfaces: CLI for automation, GUI for interaction, and 3D visualization.
  • QGIS Integration: Seamlessly load results into QGIS with our dedicated plugin.
  • Cross-Platform: Full support for Linux and Windows.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers how to set up Blaze on Linux and Windows.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Blaze requires several libraries that can be installed via the provided script: - CMake (3.20+) - GDAL - OpenCV - Qt6 - OpenMP

Run the following command from the project root:

./scripts/install-ubuntu-deps.sh

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
1. Configure the build: 

    cmake -B build

  2. Compile: 

    cmake --build build --config Release -j$(nproc)

Alternatively, use the provided build script: 

./scripts/linux-build.sh

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Option 1: Using vcpkg (Recommended)

Blaze uses vcpkg for dependency management on Windows. The build system will automatically fetch and build dependencies, though this may take some time during the first build.

Option 2: Manual Installation

You can install dependencies using Chocolatey:

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process
.\scripts\install-deps-windows.ps1

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
1. Configure the build: 

    cmake -B build

  2. Compile: 

    cmake --build build --config Release --parallel

docs.title: Windows Installer
docs.text:
To create a standalone installer (NSIS), run:

cd build
cpack -C Release -G NSIS

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Contributions are welcome! Please follow these guidelines to help maintain the quality of the project.

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub.
  2. Clone your fork locally.
  3. Create a branch for your feature or bugfix.
  4. Commit your changes following the project's coding style (see below).
  5. Push to your fork and submit a Pull Request.

docs.title: Coding Standards
docs.text:
• C++: We use C++20. Please follow the existing code style. We use .clang-format to maintain consistency.
  • Python: Follow Black formatting.
  • Pre-commit: We recommend installing pre-commit to automatically run linters before committing.
pip install pre-commit
pre-commit install

docs.title: QGIS Plugin
docs.text: The Blaze Map Loader plugin simplifies importing processed results into QGIS.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Automated Loading: Automatically loads output maps created by Blaze.
  • Magnetic North: Overlays magnetic north lines.
  • Topo Data: Integrates NSW topographic data where available.
  • Styling: Applies predefined styles to layers for consistent visualization.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Copy the qgis_plugin/blaze_loader folder to your QGIS plugins directory:
  2. Linux: ~/.local/share/QGIS/QGIS3/profiles/default/python/plugins/
  3. Windows: %APPDATA%\QGIS\QGIS3\profiles\default\python\plugins
  4. Open QGIS.
  5. Go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins.
  6. Enable Blaze Map Loader.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: Once enabled, look for the Blaze icon in your QGIS toolbar or under the Plugins menu. Use the dialog to select your Blaze output directory and load the data.

docs.title: Quick Guide
docs.text: Get started with processing LIDAR data using Blaze.

docs.title: Command-Line Interface (CLI)
docs.text: The blaze-cli is the core processing engine.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Process a single file using default settings:

./blaze-cli path/to/data.laz

docs.title: Advanced Configuration
docs.text:
You can provide a JSON configuration file to customize the processing pipeline:

./blaze-cli configs/config.json path/to/data.laz

docs.title: GUI Application
docs.text:
For a more interactive experience, use the Blaze desktop application.

  1. Launch Blaze (or Blaze.exe on Windows).
  2. Load your LAS/LAZ files via the menu.
  3. Configure processing parameters in the sidebar.
  4. View the results in the 2D map view.

docs.title: 3D Visualization
docs.text: The Blaze3D application is currently under development and provides a point cloud viewer for inspecting your data in 3D space.
